_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



At Valero Refining Company - Texas L.P. (Houston Refinery), we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:



- A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation,

- A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases,

- An overview of our accidental release prevention programs,

- A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule,

- An overview of our emergency response program,

- An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, or the environment,

- The certifications that EPA's rule requires us to provide,

- The detailed information (data elements) about our risk management program.



2 STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



Our facility is a petroleum refinery which produces gasoline, ultra low sulfur diesel, and streams for use as chemical feedstocks, using a variety of processing operations.  The regulated substances are contained within the tank farm and seven other process units. Several additional process units may contain regulated substances, but are either in mixtures that do not meet the EPA definition of a flammable mixture, or are below the RMP threshold quantities. In addition, we have included predictive filings for the Boilerhouse & Boiler #1 Unit and Crude Expansion Unit processes that will maintain RMP-regulated substances abov

e threshold quantities once that become active.  We are also deregistering the Iso-Octene and Reformer Process Units as they are currently out of service and de-inventoried.  In our processes, we use the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:



Toxics - Storage of ammonium hydroxide at/above RMP applicabiity has been added to the plan.

Flammables - Miscellaneous flammable mixtures and pure component streams, maintained in storage tanks and contained within process unit equipment.



Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us to effectively manage the hazards that may be posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these substances.



3 KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS



The RMP rule requires that we conduct studies to identify worst-case scenario(s) for each RMP-regulated process at our facility.  A summary of those applicable worst-case and alternate release scenarios including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario is provided in the appropriate section of this Risk Management Plan.  



We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.



4 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



We maintain a number of programs to help prevent accidental releases and to ensure safe operations.  The accident prevention programs in place include:



OSHA PSM elements, including:

- employee participation programs, 

- process safety information, 

- process hazard analyses, 

- operating procedures and training, 

- mechanical integrity programs with training, 

- contractor programs, 

- root cause incident investigation programs, 

-

management of change, 

- pre-startup safety reviews, 

- compliance audits, and 

- hot work and safe work programs.  



Additionally, Valero has implemented various safety programs addressing:

- safe personnel protective clothing and equipment,

- hearing protection,

- safe entry and exit controls, impact protection and secondary containment controls,

- controls on locating temporary buildings, and 

- a detailed analysis and adherence to generally accepted industry codes and standards.



We have additionally adopted the Houston area contractors training program to assure that only qualified contractor personnel may enter the facility.  Valero has made every effort to assure compliance with OSHA PSM.  Program improvements have been implemented following PSM audits with the latest occuring in 2012. Accordingly, the dates provided in Section 7, Prevention Program Level 3, represent the latest updates to the program elements.



As part of our prevention program, we have implemented many chemical-specific prevention steps.  For flammables, we have adopted several API, NFPA, insurance company, ASME, ANSI, and other codes and standards.  Our firewater system has recently been upgraded.  Additional prevention activities continue to be identified and implemented as a result of our on-going process hazard analyses.



The individual elements of our prevention program work together to help prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we meet our own high standards for accident prevention.



Valero's Houston Refinery is also an OSHA VPP STAR site, and was re-approved in 2011.



5 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



We keep records for all significant chemical releases that occur at our refinery.  There are no incidents with accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPAs RMP

rule during the past five years:



                                                                                                                                                                            

6  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan through Channel Industries Mutual Aid and the City of Houston Fire Department.  We have recently upgraded to an electronic Emergency Response Plan (EPlan-Pro)that is accessible company-wide, can submit information to the National Incident Management System electronically, and produces Emergency Plan documents tailored to specific agency requirements. 



7 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



We are continuously investigating and reviewing technology and / or applications that could possibly enhance our safety efforts.  We are constantly reviewing and revising existing procedures, developing new procedures, and researching methods to increase employee awareness.  We are continuously using learnings from incident investigations to improve our processes.
